items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely all day today, Tuesday 7th December 2021 and overnight tonight. Water levels continue to remain high. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 8th December 2021.

High tides and strong winds are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire coast on the evening of Tuesday 07/12/2021 between 4pm and midnight, and on the morning of Wednesday 08/12/2021 between 6am and midday. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to today's rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water.
Further rainfall is expected overnight and Derwent Water is forecast to remain high until Thursday.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We continue to monitor the situation and this message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Following the heavy rainfall this morning due to Storm Barra, river levels are continuing to steadily rise on the Rivers Clyst and Culm. 

Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible this afternoon, Tuesday 07/12/2021 and overnight. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Wednesday morning, 08/12/2021, or earlier if the situation changes.

The level in the River Parrett at Chiselborough is rising following the rainfall today falling on saturated ground. Further showers are forecast during Tuesday night and into Wednesday and the river will remain high over night. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible during this evening and into Wednesday. Flooding may affect roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
The Sherborne Lake level has risen following the rainfall today and there is the possibility of the flooding of local land tonight and into Wednesday. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
The River Wriggle at Chetnole and the River Cam at Weston Bampfylde remain below levels of concern. 
Further showers are forecast during Tuesday night and into Wednesday and the lake level will remain high into Wednesday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Tuesday's tides at 11:00 AM  and 11:45 PM will be higher than normal due to stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra. 
South-westerly force 8 winds and large waves will produce a swell within the harbour.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour side and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
We are closing flood gates in the area.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive or walk through flood water.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

The high tide at  00:30 AM on Wednesday will be higher than normal due to stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra. 
South-westerly force 8 winds and large waves will produce a swell within the harbour.
Areas most at risk include The Quomps, Mudeford and the Stanpit area
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive or walk through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Wey as a result of rainfall during Storm Barra. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected later this evening, 07/12/21, especially in the Passfield Mill area.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high, and levels are sensitive to further rainfall.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 08/12/21.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message: River levels remain high at the Great Bridgford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today into tomorrow, Wednesday 08/12/2021. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook. Further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Wednesday 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the Littlemead Brook / Cranleigh Waters as a result of rainfall during Storm Barra. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected this evening, 07/12/2021. 
Heavy rain showers are forecast over the next 24 hours, and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
Our incident response staff are liaising with the council to carry out trash screen clearance at Ewhurst Road.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/12/21.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Lilbourne  river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 18:00 today, 07/12/21. 
Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Wednesday 08/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Hints river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high overnight and into Wednesday 08/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin overnight Tuesday, 07/12/2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.7m to 3.9m  Wednesday evening, 08/12; Cae Howel 4.3m to 4.6m Thursday afternoon, 09/12.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen overnight as a result of heavy rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from approximately 6am today, Wednesday 08 December 2021 at Kinnersley Manor, and is also possible along the River Mole as far as Cobham.  We expect flooding to affect land and roads.  Property flooding is not currently expected.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 5 days.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing trash screens and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Southam river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from  20:00 today, 07/12/21.
Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Wednesday 08/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. Stay aware in case further warnings are issued.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force as river levels remain high following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Tuesday 07/12/2021, and on Wednesday 08/12/2021. Further rainfall is forecast on Wednesday, and river levels could remain high until later in the week. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton has been removed. The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area.

This flood alert remains in force. Large and powerful waves are still possible due to strong winds of Storm Barra which is passing over the region. The risk of flooding and hazardous conditions at beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths remains but will ease through the night into the morning of Wednesday 8th Dec. Areas most at risk are Beadnell Harbour Rd North, Berwick Dock and Main Road.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 9:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences.  The first forecast high water is 21:00 on 07/12/21, with a level of 6.58 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. The second forecast high water is 09:15 on 08/12/21, with a level of 6.19 mAOD and a Force 8 Westerly wind.
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding to coastal areas and the most vulnerable properties is possible tonight and tomorrow morning and may occur one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Strong winds are forecast again for Wednesday evening and this flood alert may remain in force for the high tide at 21:45.

items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at Sandside at 1:45am on 08/12/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra, this may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast.
Forecasts indicate further alerts may be issued for the lunchtime tide on Wednesday.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the forecast high water is 21:30am on 07/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.40 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 9 in a westerley direction. There is a possibility of flooding for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham, and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehamption Park, including Pill and Shirehampton, however conditions may apply one/two hours either side of the high tide.
Our operation teams are closing flood gates in the Pill and Shirehampton area. 
Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 1 AM on 08/12/2021.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road and Arpley Bridge. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge between 2:45 AM and 3.30AM on 08/12/2021.
River levels at Fiddlers Ferry will peak at 6.58m between 2 AM and 3 AM. 
River levels at Eastford Road will peak at 6.71m between 2.15 AM and 3.15AM. 
River levels at Arpley Bridge will peak at 6.41m between 2:45 AM and 3.30AM. 
Further high tides are expected at these locations tomorrow, 8 December 2021, from 15:00PM.  Our incident response staff will closely monitor the situation and will update this alert tomorrow morning (8/12/21), or as the situation changes.
Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

Strong winds from storm Barra are likely to cause high tidal peaks in the Wye Estuary. The tides will be at their highest at Newport between 21:00 and 22:00 this evening, 07/12/21 where they may exceed the flood alert threshold. 
Flooding is possible and may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.2m to 7.4m at 21:15 on 07/12, Newport 7.0m to 7.2m at 21:15 on 07/12.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning by 10am, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast on Tuesday. Flooding is possible over high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. 

High water at Ilfracombe is at 08:15 PM on Tuesday 07/12/2021 and at 08:30 AM on Wednesday 08/12/2021, times of high water will vary along the coast. Force 9 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 9.7m are forecast, which could result in wave overtopping of sea defences and localised flooding in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be up to 0.6m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Tuesday 07/12/2021 at 08:15 PM is 4.81 mAOD, this is 0.60 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at Braystones Beach at 1:40am on 08/12/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra, this may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast.
Properties on the foreshore at Braystones, Nethertown and Coulderton are at risk.
Forecasts indicate further alerts may be issued for the lunchtime tide on Wednesday.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
This flood alert remains in force. Large and powerful waves are still possible due to strong winds of Storm Barra which is passing over the region. The risk of flooding and hazardous conditions at beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths remains but will ease through the night into the morning of Wednesday 8th Dec. Areas most at risk are North Shields Western Quay Prom, Seaburn Lower Prom, Roker Seafront, Hendon Promenade, Seaham Harbour and Docks. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 9:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.33 m. The total forecast tide is 5.08 metres Chart Datum (2.35 mAOD) at Portsmouth. The tide will be much lower than it was this afternoon, but the residual impacts from Storm Barra may still cause some minor impact flooding. If impacts do occur, they will be relatively minor and confined to the immediate sea front. For 30 minutes either side of high tide, the water level may be high at South Street and Queen Street, Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park and Langstone High Street may experience some very shallow water flooding. Waves may cause some spray overtopping around The Promenade. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. As a very precautionary measure, and if you have it, you may wish to leave flood protection installed until tomorrow morning (08/12/2021). We will remove this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021.

The combination of spring tides, a large tidal surge and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences. The forecast high water is 21:30 on 07/12/21 with a level of 7.4 mAOD and a Force 8 South Westerly wind. 
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth and mAOD is height above average sea level. For more details, refer to local tide tables. As a result, the flooding of coastal areas, roads and the most vulnerable properties is possible at these times and may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade.

We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates. This flood alert is unlikely to be reissued again during this period of spring tides. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.16 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 1 hour either side of high water, Mill Lane, Sidlesham will flood, making access temporarily more difficult. Wind blown spray and wave overtopping will likely affect exposed beach top properties between Selsey Bill and Elmer. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, and flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. Avoid driving on Mill Lane at high tide. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.16 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high water, the tide could cause minor flooding to boatyards and the industrial areas along Littlehampton Rope Walk and could be high up slipways. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.16 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, shallow water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front. Water will pond in Climping Street Car Park and may flow westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels and flood risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. We recycled shingle in November and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:30 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.24 m. The total forecast tide is 5.06 metres Chart Datum (2.32 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water could be near to or flood front door steps. Around Chichester harbour, some gardens or land at shore side properties could also be affected. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels and flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

items.description: Mersey Estuary from Liverpool and Wirral to Widnes

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast on 08/12/2021. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the Mersey Estuary.
River levels at Hale Village is expected to peak at 6.02m between 2 AM and 2.45AM.
After this tide we do not expect further high tides at this location.
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 8/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is expected for: Areas at risk include Marine Point Leisure and Retail Park and properties on King's Parade and Marine Promenade.    
Immediate action required. 
Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast in the early hours of tomorrow morning.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at Marine Point Leisure and Retail Park.
Flooding is expected to affect Marine Point Leisure and Retail Park between 1:15 AM and 2.45AM on 08/12/2021.
Weather conditions are expected to produce large onshore waves.
Further high tides are expected at this location tomorrow, 8 December 2021, from 1:45PM.  Our incident response staff will closely monitor the situation and will update this flood warning tomorrow morning (8/12/21), or as the situation changes.
Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous.

This flood warning remains in force. Large and powerful waves are still possible due to strong winds of Storm Barra which is passing over the region. The risk of flooding and hazardous conditions at beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths remains but will ease through the night into the morning of Wednesday 8th Dec. The area most at risk is Roker Seafront We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Irish Sea from New Brighton to Hoylake
items.message:
Flooding is possible for: Areas at risk include land at the head of the Wirral from Hoylake to New Brighton and including parts of Leasowe and Wallasey.    
Wednesday morning's tide at 01:15 AM is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with north-westerly force 5 to 7 winds and large waves.
Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast from between 1.15AM and 2.45AM.
Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. 
We do not expect to see similar impacts for tomorrow's high tides. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes

items.description: North Sea at Berwick-Upon-Tweed and Tweedmouth
items.message:
This flood warning remains in force. Large and powerful waves are still possible due to strong winds of Storm Barra which is passing over the region. The risk of flooding and hazardous conditions at beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths remains but will ease through the night into the morning of Wednesday 8th Dec. Areas most at risk are Berwick Dock and Main Road. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington - Harbour Road and Floral Pavilion
items.message: The flood warning for the North Sea at Bridlington has been removed. The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area.

floodArea.county: Hartlepool, North Yorkshire, Redcar and Cleveland

items.message:
This flood alert remains in force. Large and powerful waves are still possible due to strong winds of Storm Barra which is passing over the region. The risk of flooding and hazardous conditions at beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths remains but will ease through the night into the morning of Wednesday 8th Dec. Areas most at risk are North Headland to Breakwater, Town Wall and Croft on Heugh.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 9:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Camel excluding Wadebridge and Chapel Amble
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at Padstow is at 19:36 on Tuesday 7th December and 07:59 on Wednesday 8th December, times of high water will vary along the coast.  

Strong Force 8 westerly winds, veering north westerly, and offshore wave heights of 6-10m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  

Locations particularly at risk include the A389 at Sladesbridge.  

Expect tides to be around 700mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.  

With strong wind and large waves seafront areas will be dangerous. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.     

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.   

This message will be updated on the morning of Wednesday 8th December.

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at St Ives is at 19:19 Tuesday 7th December and 07:44 Wednesday 8th December, times of high water will vary along the coast.  

Strong Force 8 westerly winds, veering north westerly, and offshore wave heights of  6-10m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including St Ives Harbour, Portreath Harbour and the Causeway at Hayle.

With strong wind and large waves seafront areas will be dangerous. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.     

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.  

This message will be updated on the morning of Wednesday 8th December.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:18 on 08/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.48 m. The total forecast tide is 4.14 metres Chart Datum (2.14 mAOD) at Beaulieu. The tide will be much lower than it was this afternoon, but the residual impacts from Storm Barra may still cause some very minor impact flooding. For 30 minutes either side of high water, it is possible that some road flooding may occur at Palace Lane. The tide may also flood into the garden of the Mill House on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled, and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if driving through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood the main road quickly. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:18 and 03:18 on 08/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.48 m. The total forecast tide is 5.04 metres Chart Datum (2.3 mAOD) at Southampton. The tide will be much lower than it was this afternoon, but the residual impacts from Storm Barra may still cause some minor impact flooding. For 30 minutes either side of high water, footpath flooding may affect some areas within Riverside Park. The pub car park at Mansbridge, may see minor impact flooding for a short period of time. Any flood depth would be relatively shallow. The tide will not flood property or the A27. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled, and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. As a very precautionary measure, please consider closing the defence gates around the pub. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021.

items.description: Somerset coast at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean
items.message:
The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences.  The first forecast high water is 21:00 on 07/12/21, with a level of 6.58 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. The second forecast high water is 09:15 on 08/12/21, with a level of 6.19 mAOD and a Force 8 Westerly wind.
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding of coastal areas including roads and farmland is possible at these times. However, conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are coastal areas at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean.  Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point and this flood alert is unlikely to be reissued during this period of spring tides. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences. The first forecast high water is 21:00 on 07/12/21, with a level of 6.58 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. The second forecast high water is 09:15 on 08/12/2021, with a level of 6.19 mAOD and a Force 8 Westerly wind. 
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level.
There is the possibility of flooding of the most vulnerable properties and this may occur one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk include properties on the lockside, businesses around the Harbour Masters office, Gibraltar Cottages and other low lying properties on the B3225 at Porlock Weir. High winds will continue during Wednesday but this flood warning is unlikely to be in force for the high tide at 21:45 due to falling high tides.

Please consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Cumbrian coastline from St Bees Head to Millom, along the coast from North Head to Haverigg
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 1:40am on 08/12/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra, this may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast.
Properties on the foreshore at Braystones, Nethertown and Coulderton are at risk.
Forecasts indicate further warnings may be issued for the lunchtime tide on Wednesday.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the South Devon coast. 
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at Teignmouth is at 08:45 PM on Tuesday 07/12/2021 and at 09:00 AM on Wednesday 08/12/2021, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
Force 7 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 1.5m are forecast on Tuesday evening, which could result in wave overtopping of sea defences and localised flooding in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be up to 0.48m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes. 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Teignmouth on Tuesday 07/12/2021 at 08:45 PM is 2.34 mAOD, this is 0.48m above astronomical tide level.

items.description: South Devon coast from Dawlish Warren to Seaton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the South Devon coast. 
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at Exmouth is at 09:00 PM on Tuesday 07/12/2021 and at 09:15 AM on Wednesday 08/12/2021, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
Force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 1.6m are forecast on Tuesday evening, which could result in wave overtopping of sea defences and localised flooding in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be up to 0.33m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes. 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Exmouth on Tuesday 07/12/2021 at 09:00 PM is 2.12 mAOD, this is 0.33m above astronomical tide level.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:09 and 03:09 on 08/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.46 m. The total forecast tide is 3.79 metres Chart Datum (1.81 mAOD) at Lymington. For 1 hour either side of high tide, small amounts of water will flood the footpath near the Ship Inn pub at Town Quay. Saltgrass Lane will flood and will be impassable to traffic. Property flooding is not expected. After this tide‚ the weather becomes more settled, and no further impacts are expected. To protect property from flooding, at Keyhaven and Lymington, we will close our tidal defence gates for 2 hours either side of high water. We recommend that all private defence gates are closed. Any cars parked at Saltgrass Lane will flood. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:18 and 03:18 on 08/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.48 m. The total forecast tide is 5.04 metres Chart Datum (2.3 mAOD) at Southampton. The tide will be much lower than it was this afternoon, but the residual impacts from Storm Barra may still cause some minor impact flooding along the estuary front. For 30 minutes either side of high water, the tide may affect roads and car parks at The Quay Hamble, Rising Sun Pub Warsash, Magazine Lane at Marchwood, Shore Road and Promenade, Hythe. After this tide‚ the weather becomes more settled, and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid parking in low lying coastal car parks and plan driving routes to avoid the roads listed above. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:30 on 08/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.48 m. The total forecast tide is 4.79 metres Chart Datum (2.20 mAOD) at Cowes. The tide will be much lower than it was this afternoon, but the residual impacts from Storm Barra may still cause some minor impact flooding, especially as wave heights are larger. For 1 hour either side of high water, minor impact flooding will affect some sea front roads, esplanades and car parks across the island, especially at more exposed locations such as Freshwater Bay, Shanklin and Gurnard. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled, and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid driving or parking at the sea front at high tide. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021.

The tide level is now reducing. The tide forecast in the early hours of Wednesday morning (08/12/2021) at 01:45 remains a little elevated, but it is no longer expected to cause property or minor impact flooding.

floodArea.riverOrSea: The Solent, Portsmouth Harbour, Langstone Harbour

items.message: Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.33 m. The total forecast tide is 5.08 metres Chart Datum (2.35 mAOD) at Portsmouth. The tide will be much lower than it was this afternoon, but the residual impacts from Storm Barra may still cause some minor impact flooding. For 1 hour either side of high water, spray overtopping of defence walls at Southsea promenade and Eastern Road is expected. To protect property in Old Portsmouth, tidal defence gates will be closed. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled, and no further impacts are expected. We are liaising with the local authority over flood defence gate closures. Avoid the exposed sea front at high tide, especially Southsea. Spray and large waves can carry and throw shingle and debris. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.33 m. The total forecast tide is 5.08 metres Chart Datum (2.35 mAOD) at Portsmouth. The tide will be much lower than it was this afternoon, but the residual impacts from Storm Barra may still cause some minor impact flooding. For 1 hour either side of high water, the main road at Northney will flood. At South Hayling, large waves may move and remove shingle on the beach. This may cause garden and minor impact road flooding, at the immediate sea front. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We are liaising with the local authority over beach condition at South Hayling. Avoid the sea front at high tide. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.33 m. The total forecast tide is 5.08 metres Chart Datum (2.35 mAOD) at Portsmouth. The tide will be much lower than it was this afternoon, but the residual impacts from Storm Barra may still cause some minor impact flooding. For 30 minutes either side of high water, spray overtopping of sea defence walls into low lying coastal roads between Hillhead and Gosport, namely Cliff Road and Stokes Bay Road, is expected. At Hillhead, low lying sea front car parks may flood. Property flooding is not expected. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled, and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. Be careful if driving at Gosport sea front at high tide. Large waves can carry and throw shingle and debris, which could affect the main road at Stokes Bay. We will remove this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021.

A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the first forecast high water is 21:30 on 07/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.40 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 9 in a westerly direction. The time and date of the second forecast high water is 09:45 on 08/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 6.95 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 8 in a westerly direction. 
There is a possibility of flooding for the Severn estuary at Severn Beach, including New Passage and Pilning. Conditions may apply one/two hours either side of the high tide.
Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Rame Head to Plymouth including tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tide on Tuesday 7th December. High water at Plymouth is at 20:04. Times of high water will vary along the coast 

Strong Force 7 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 5m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Locations particularly at risk include: Kingsand, Cawsand, harbours and coastal car parks, ferry terminals and quaysides exposed to the open sea and vulnerable to large waves.  Expect tides to be around 350mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.  

With strong winds and large waves, sea front areas will be dangerous. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.  

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.  

This message will be updated on the morning of Wednesday 8th December.

items.message: Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. Winds are forecast to be West South Westerly Force 7, gusting to gale Force 8 at times. Time of high water at locations along the East Dorset Coast is as follows: Weymouth Preston Beach at 21:00 and 09:15, Swanage Bay at 22:55 and 09:55, Poole Harbour at Wareham at 01:00 and 13:15, and Christchurch Harbour at 00:30 and 12:45. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Stay away from exposed beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 15:00 on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping at the coast on Wednesday morning, especially at West Bay, Lyme Regis and Chiswell. Winds are forecast to be West South Westerly Force 7, gusting to gale Force 8 at times. Time of high water at locations along the West Dorset Coast is at 09:20 Wednesday 08/12/2021. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Stay away from exposed beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Avoid walking close to cliffs due to the high risk of rock falls in the prevailing conditions. This message will be updated by 13:00 on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
The high tide at 00:30 AM on Wednesday will be higher than normal due to conditions associated with Storm Barra. 
South-westerly force 8 winds and large waves will produce a swell within the harbour.
Areas most at risk include Wareham Quayside and Hamworthy.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive or walk through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

The tide level is now reducing and it is no longer expected to cause property flooding. The tide forecast in the early hours of Wednesday morning (08/12/2021) at 01:45 remains a little elevated, with larger waves. As there is a small possibility that some very minor impact flooding may occur, a Flood Alert will remain in force for this tide. The Flood Alert will be issued shortly.
The tide level is now reducing. The tide forecast in the early hours of Wednesday morning (08/12/2021) at 01:45 remains a little elevated, but it is no longer expected to cause property flooding.

items.message:
This flood warning remains in force. Large and powerful waves are still possible due to strong winds of Storm Barra which is passing over the region. The risk of flooding and hazardous conditions at beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths remains but will ease through the night into the morning of Wednesday 8th Dec. Areas most at risk are Town Wall and Croft on Heugh. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:30 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.11 m. The total forecast tide is 6.89 metres Chart Datum (3.37 mAOD) at Newhaven. For 2 hours either side of high water, a small amount of spray overtopping will affect footpaths, sea front parking and the road at Marine Parade and the Esplanade. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, and flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. At low tide we will check and work to maintain the condition of the shingle beach which helps to protect the town from flooding. Avoid walking, parking and driving along Seaford Sea Front at high tide. Spray and water will contain and scatter shingle which is dangerous. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.09 m. The total forecast tide is 7.49 metres Chart Datum (3.84 mAOD) at Eastbourne. For 2 hours either side of high water, the road at Herbrand Walk may flood, and could be impassable to traffic. Beach top properties at Pevensey Bay will be affected by spray, caused by the large waves. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, and flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. To protect property from flooding, at low tide, Pevensey Coastal Defence Ltd will maintain the condition of the shingle beach. Avoid Pevensey beach at high tide. Spray and waves will contain and scatter shingle which is dangerous. As a precaution, plan driving routes to avoid Herbrand Walk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

items.description: Coastal areas of Rustington to Shoreham
items.message: Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.16 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high water, spray overtopping will affect footpaths and esplanades including Marine Drive at Ferring, West and Marine Parade, Worthing and West Beach and Shoreham Beach, Shoreham. Shingle and ponded water could affect the A259 near Brooklands. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. We may inspect the condition of the beach at low tide. Stormy seas are dangerous. Avoid walking along the sea front over high tide, shingle can be contained, carried and thrown in larger waves and spray. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon, seafront properties
items.message:
The combination of spring tides, a large tidal surge and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences. The forecast high water is 21:30 on 07/12/21 with a level of 7.4 mAOD and a Force 8 South Westerly wind. 

All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth and mAOD is height above average sea level. For more details, refer to local tide tables. As a result, the flooding of the most vulnerable properties is possible at these times and may be at risk one to two hours either side of the high tide.

Flooding is possible on the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade including the Marine Lake, Elton Road and The Beach. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates. This flood warning is unlikely to be reissued again during this period of spring tides. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Storm Barra has brought  strong, Force 7, south westerly winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. 
High water will be at about 10:00 pm this evening, Tuesday 07/12/2021.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the weather conditions.
Areas most at risk include The Sea Life Centre and the Preston Beach Road area of Lodmoor.
Our incident response staff are in the area and will be checking local defences.
Plan driving routes to avoid Preston Beach Road which may be affected by flooding.
Stay away from Weymouth beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 10:00 AM on 08/12/2021.

Storm Barra has brought  strong, Force 7, south westerly winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. 
High water will be at about 10:00 pm this evening, Tuesday 07/12/2021, although levels will remain high for several hours afterwards.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the weather conditions.
Areas most at risk include the inner harbour, East Beach and the esplanade on East Beach.
Our incident response staff are in the area and will be checking local defences.
Avoid going near cliffs as the risk of cliff falls is considerably raised during storm conditions.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 10:00 AM on 08/12/2021.

The River Uck is high and rising. Storm Barra has brought 15mm of rain Tuesday afternoon. From 19:45 on 07/12/2021 minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub and areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. Only minimal impacts are expected in Uckfield from 21:00 on 07/12/2021 at The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage & Bell Walk. From 23:00 on 07/12/2021 flood water will likely affect fields and gardens at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge. Further showers are possible overnight, but are expected to bring less than 5mm of rain. We think the river should begin to fall by 22:00 on 07/12/2021, in Buxted and 07:00 on 08/12/2021 in Isfield, returning to normal by midday Wednesday. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding, including using flood protection products if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:30 on 08/12/2021.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
Further light rainfall is forecast for tonight, Wednesday 8th December 2021 but we do not expect this to cause any further impacts.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
River levels remain high following heavy rainfall from storm Barra. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today, Wednesday 8th December 2021. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Great Stour and the River East Stour, particularly in and around Ashford and around Stone Cross. 
Further light rainfall is forecast tonight Wednesday 8th December 2021.  
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
This message will be updated this evening, Wednesday 8th December 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield, Penshurst and particularly on and around Balls Green. 
Further light rainfall is forecast tonight, Wednesday 8th December 2021. 
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, Wednesday 8th December 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Hampstead Lock at Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of Storm Barra. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 5am and 8pm today, Wednesday 8th December 2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the river, particularly in the Staplehurst area.   
Further light rainfall is forecast for tonight, Wednesday 8th December 2021.  We expect river levels to remain high until 8pm on Wednesday 8th December 2021.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated  this evening, Wednesday 8th December 2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen as a result of Storm Barra.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 5am and 8pm today Wednesday 8th December 2021. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Medway particularly footpaths and riverside areas in the Maidstone area and particularly around Aylesford. 
Further light rainfall is forecast for tonight, Wednesday 8th December 2021.  We expect river levels to remain high until 8pm on Wednesday 8th December 2021.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  this evening, Wednesday 8th December 2021, or as the situation changes.
